It’s in the client you play with. This was a client side tip, so it works on real servers as it works on private servers (only a client side change).

item.title: Pets
item.dc:creator: @danward danward
item.description:
@danward wrote:

[quote=“daiki, post:3, topic:900”][quote author=xerozcheez link=topic=793.msg7342#msg7342 date=1143613369]
If you mean by the npc model or npc name then yeah, in fact anything can be changed with a simple client hack, unfortunatly not many people know how to do this.
[/quote] I’ve never done this, but I’m sure this trick would do it:

First we find the class where the NPCs are handled in.
Search for “level” in the client.java. There should be two of those in there. Take the one that has "Use " + aString* + " with @yel@" a few lines down.

Okay. In the “(level-” + class*.anInt* + “)” we see, that the class X is used to handle NPCs.

Let’s open up the class32.java (or what ever it is called in the latest deob) and look for “return class32;”. Notice the ; after the class and number.

You should find only one method:

    public static Class32 method537(int i)
    {
        for(int j = 0; j < 20; j++)
            if(aClass32Array594[j].aLong586 == (long)i)
                return aClass32Array594[j];

        anInt591 = (anInt591 + 1) % 20;
        Class32 class32 = aClass32Array594[anInt591] = new Class32();
        aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578.anInt1445 = anIntArray584[i];
        class32.aLong586 = i;
        class32.method541((byte)-11, aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578);
        return class32;
    }

Let’s try make it like this:

    public static Class32 method537(int i)
    {
        if (i >= 761 && i <= 766) //If the NPC is a kitten..
            i = 50;                //.. make it a King Black Dragon.
        for(int j = 0; j < 20; j++)
            if(aClass32Array594[j].aLong586 == (long)i)
                return aClass32Array594[j];

        anInt591 = (anInt591 + 1) % 20;
        Class32 class32 = aClass32Array594[anInt591] = new Class32();
        aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578.anInt1445 = anIntArray584[i];
        class32.aLong586 = i;
        class32.method541((byte)-11, aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578);
        return class32;
    }

Tried this and it works. Fun fun :)[/quote]

where is the class32.java? or what is it?

Read full topic

item.title: Pets
item.dc:creator: @daiki daiki
item.description:
@daiki wrote:

[quote=“xerozcheez, post:13, topic:900”][quote author=daiki link=topic=793.msg7474#msg7474 date=1143657426]
A lot easier? How can it be easier than adding two lines? You’re all crazy.
[/quote]

Umm if you want to rename every npc its easier in client, but it would be alot easier to go into the cache folder and edit each npc if you just wanted to edit some…[/quote]
No. Renaming only is done in the cache files. Replacing the whole npc can be done with those two lines.

Please write me a guide where you change a cat or kitten to a king black dragon with the cache files.[br][size=1]Posted at: March 29, 2006, 11:07:05 pm[/size][hr]Oh. My apologies. I was looking at the wrong method in the monster class. I’ll update that “tutorial” right away. I tried this now, it works.

Updated it

Read full topic

item.title: Pets
item.dc:creator: @daiki daiki
item.description:
@daiki wrote:

[quote=“xerozcheez, post:5, topic:900”]Umm the npc stuff isn’t in the client.java, its in the cache folder…if you didn’t even know that then you’re gonna get no where lol =[/quote]Sure it is in the client.java. Client java reads the cache folder. You will just make it read differently.

Oh. I get your point. You mean the server’s client.java. I meant the client.java for the RuneScape client :).
What happened to the good old client hacking days? (Maybe it’s just because this is server development section…)

And I don’t think private servers even support cats yet. Maybe this whole topic should be moved to client hacking section.

Read full topic

item.title: Pets
item.dc:creator: @daiki daiki
item.description:
@daiki wrote:

[quote=“xerozcheez, post:2, topic:900”]If you mean by the npc model or npc name then yeah, in fact anything can be changed with a simple client hack, unfortunatly not many people know how to do this. :)[/quote] I’ve never done this, but I’m sure this trick would do it:

First we find the class where the NPCs are handled in.
Search for “level” in the client.java. There should be two of those in there. Take the one that has "Use " + aString* + " with @yel@" a few lines down.

Okay. In the “(level-” + class*.anInt* + “)” we see, that the class X is used to handle NPCs.

Let’s open up the class32.java (or what ever it is called in the latest deob) and look for “return class32;”. Notice the ; after the class and number.

You should find only one method:

    public static Class32 method537(int i)
    {
        for(int j = 0; j < 20; j++)
            if(aClass32Array594[j].aLong586 == (long)i)
                return aClass32Array594[j];

        anInt591 = (anInt591 + 1) % 20;
        Class32 class32 = aClass32Array594[anInt591] = new Class32();
        aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578.anInt1445 = anIntArray584[i];
        class32.aLong586 = i;
        class32.method541((byte)-11, aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578);
        return class32;
    }

Let’s try make it like this:

    public static Class32 method537(int i)
    {
        if (i >= 761 && i <= 766) //If the NPC is a kitten..
            i = 50;                //.. make it a King Black Dragon.
        for(int j = 0; j < 20; j++)
            if(aClass32Array594[j].aLong586 == (long)i)
                return aClass32Array594[j];

        anInt591 = (anInt591 + 1) % 20;
        Class32 class32 = aClass32Array594[anInt591] = new Class32();
        aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578.anInt1445 = anIntArray584[i];
        class32.aLong586 = i;
        class32.method541((byte)-11, aClass19_Sub1_Sub1_578);
        return class32;
    }

Tried this and it works. Fun fun

Read full topic
